title: The Oath
text: Hannibal Barca is only nine when his father asks him the question that will change his life forever. Hannibal must choose to stay in the safety of Carthage or go with his father to conquer Spain. Hannibal chooses to go to war. Before he can go, Hannibal's father has him perform a bloody ritual. Hannibal lays his hand on an animal while it is sacrificed to the god Ba'al Shamin and swears to never be a friend to Rome. Once this is complete, Hannibal sails off to war with his father and brothers.

title: The Conquest of Spain
text: Hamilcar leads his men against the 50,000 strong army of the Spanish chieftain Indortes. Terrified by the Carthaginians, Indortes' army flees before the battle even begins. Hamilcar and his army trap Indortes and his army in a nearby town. At night, Indortes tries to escape. Instead, the Carthaginians capture him and many of his men. Hamilcar has Indortes blinded and crucified. He shows leniency to the men, however, and lets all 10,000 of his other prisoners go free. Hamilcar uses this mixture of violence and mercy to conquer much of Spain in only eight years. In 228 BCE, he dies in an ambush. Some sources say he died making sure that his sons escaped alive.

title: The Siege of Saguntum
text: Nine years later, Hannibal has taken his deceased father's place. Though he is less than 30 years-old, Hannibal has spent most of his life at war and is a skilled general.  In 219 BCE, Hannibal besieges the strategic stronghold of Saguntum. Saguntum is an ally of Rome, but the Romans do not send help.  It is possible the Romans want Hannibal to capture the city to justify a new war with Carthage. Over eight months Hannibal's army takes more and more of Saguntum. After one final attack, the Carthaginian army breaks into Saguntum's last defenses. Hannibal offers the citizens a deal: he will allow them to walk away free, “unarmed and each with two garments.” The citizens refuse. After that, Hannibal has every adult killed.

title: It Will Be War
text: After the massacre at Saguntum, Rome sends an embassy to Carthage to demand justice. They want the Carthaginian leaders to hand Hannibal over so Rome can punish him. The Carthaginian senate refuses. The Roman senator Fabius says, "I hold in my toga both peace and war." It is up to the Carthaginians to decide which it will be. When the Carthaginians do not answer, Fabius says that the Romans will go to war. In reply, the entire Carthaginian senate shouts, "We accept."

title: Hannibal Plans
text: Hannibal prepares for a war unlike any the Romans could have anticipated. His plan is to take the war to them. He sends lavish gifts to the Gallic tribes near Roman territory to gain their friendship. Hannibal also splits his army up. He sends 16,000 soldiers to defend Carthage. He leaves another 15,000 to defend Spain. For his invasion of Italy Hannibal brings 102,000 men. Not only was this 102,000 man army enormous, it was also likely one of the most well-experienced armies at the time. Hannibal also brought 32 war elephants.

title: Through the Alps
text: Hannibal leads his men through the cold and dangerous Alps mountain range. Thousands of his men die from starvation and the cold. Others desert the army instead of carrying on. Gallic tribes also add to the danger. They attack Hannibal's army and roll huge boulders onto unsuspecting soldiers. Hannibal stops the Gauls with a clever ambush, but can do nothing to stop the cold and starvation. By the time he walks out of the Alps, Hannibal only has about 26,000 men remaining.

title: Roman Disaster at Trebia
text: A huge Roman army is nearby to stop Hannibal's invasion. The night before the two armies battle, Hannibal sets an ambush. He puts his younger brother, Mago, in charge of 1,000 cavalry and 1,000 infantry who hide from view. The next morning, Hannibal sends the Numidian cavalry to harass the Roman garrison. Without time to eat, the surprised Roman army comes rushing out after the Numidians. The Roman give chase for miles, wearing themselves out and wading through the Trebia. The well-fed, warm, and rested Carthaginian army is waiting for them. The Numidian cavalry soon win the upper hand, but the infantry battle is fierce. Even when Mago springs the ambush, the Romans do not flee. The Roman center routs the Carthaginian center. However, these lucky Romans see that their army has no chance of victory and flee to the city of Placentia. The Carthaginians do not give chase. The Romans lose about 28,000 men while Hannibal loses only about 5,000.

title: Defeat at Lake Trasimene
text: After a difficult march in which Hannibal loses his right eye, the Carthaginian army arrives in the South West. They begin to lay waste to the countryside, looting and burning fields of crops. The Romans are furious at what Hannibal is doing. Already, a new Roman army is on its way to stop the Carthaginians. Many of the Roman soldiers are volunteers who expect an easy victory. Some have bought chains to hold the enemy prisons they hope to capture. When the Roman army finds the Carthaginians, they line up in battle formation. However, the general Gaius Flaminius sends out no scouts and does not know exactly where his enemy is. Little does he know that the entire Carthaginian army is hiding along the slopes of a nearby hill. The Romans only find out when their vanguard bumps into the hidden Carthaginians. The Romans are taken completely by surprise. With Hannibal's army coming down from all sides, the Romans don't even know what direction to face. The Carthaginians kill about 15,000 Romans and capture another 15,000.

title: Rome in Terror
text: After their second defeat, the Romans decide to turn to an old tradition: the dictatorship. They elect Quintus Fabius Maximus dictator. The defeated general, Gaius Flaminius, had not done the proper rites the year before. Fabius believes the disaster might be the wrath of the gods. In addition to performing all the appropriate rituals, Fabius convinces the senate to consult the ancient Sibylline Books. He also raises an army of 40,000 men.

title: Daring Escape at Ager Falernus
text: With his new army, Fabius follows Hannibal but never gives battle. After two military disasters, Fabius does not want to risk a third. Instead, Fabius has his men attack Hannibal’s foraging parties and has the citizens take all the food behind strongholds. This strategy deprives Hannibal of food sources.  In September 217 BCE, Fabius manages to trap Hannibal in the Falernian Plains. Fabius has 4,000 men defending the exit with the rest of his army camped nearby. Hannibal has his men tie sticks to the horns of 2,000 oxen. At night, he has a unit of javelinmen set these sticks on fire and drive the flaming oxen up a nearby hill. The 4,000 Romans guarding the pass chase the oxen, which they think are the entire enemy army. With the Romans chasing oxen, Hannibal leads his army through the now undefended pass. Fabius’ officers urge him to attack, but he refuses. The next morning, Hannibal sends Spanish swordsmen to save the javelinmen who were still fighting the 4,000 Romans.

title: Cannae
text: After Fabius’ term as dictator ends, Rome raises the largest army in its history. It numbers 80,000 infantry and 6,000 cavalry. This massive army manages to trap Hannibal and his 50,000 men in the hilltop town of Cannae. With the Romans so close, Hannibal's men cannot forage for food. Running out of food, Hannibal is forced to march his vastly outnumbered army out for battle. The Roman battle plan is to burst through the center of the enemy’s line as quickly as possible. At first, the battle goes as the Romans expect. The Numidian cavalry defeat their Roman counterparts but the Roman infantry fights well. Too well. They soon find themselves surrounded on either side by the best of Hannibal’s fighters: the Libyan spearmen.  The Libyan soldiers close in from either side on the now disorganized and confused Roman center. The Romans are now surrounded. The Carthaginian cavalry now charge the Roman formation from behind. The entire Roman army is now surrounded and densely packed together. Over the next several hours Hannibal’s army slaughters almost all of them. In all, about 48,000 Romans are killed and another 21,500 are captured. Hannibal loses about 5,500 men.

title: The Aftermath
text: The Roman Senate refuses to pay the ransom for any soldiers captured at Cannae. They also forbid any citizen from doing so. They declare a thirty day period of mourning. Two Vestal Virgins are condemned for allegedly breaking their vow of chastity. They are sentenced to be buried alive. The Romans also turn to human sacrifice, burying a foreign man and woman alive in the Forum Boarium. The Romans also raise a new army. To fill it, they have to accept seventeen year-olds, criminals, debtors, and slaves. To help arm this motley army, they take weapons and armor from temples. At the same time, Hannibal is stronger than ever with more people defecting to him all the time.

title: Hasdrubal Defeated at Dertosa
text: The Carthaginian general Hasdrubal Barca attempts to march his army into Italy and assist his brother Hannibal. On his way, he instigates a battle with a Roman force besieging a city in Spain. Hasdrubal tries a similar maneuver to the one Hannibal employed at Cannae. Despite their advantage in numbers, his cavalry lose to the Roman horsemen. This allows the Roman infantry to defeat their opposition and win a crushing victory.

title: Treachery in Tarentum
text: A conspiracy of young aristocrats led by a man named Philemenus plans to betray the Roman port city of Tarentum to Hannibal. Philemenus begins hunting at night, claiming it’s his way to avoid Hannibal’s patrols. Whenever he returns, he shares whatever he’d killed with the sentries and commander who open the gate for him. The sentries come to appreciate these nighttime snacks and open the gate whenever Philemenus whistles. During a celebration, some of the conspirators make sure that the Roman commander gets very drunk. At one gate, the conspirators surprise the guards, kill them, and let Hannibal and 10,000 of his men in. At the same time, Philemenus and three others approach another gate carrying a boar. Philemenus blows his whistle and the sentry open the gate as usual. When the sentry leans in to get a look at the boar, Philemenus kills him with his hunting spear. Thirty Libyan soldiers then rush in and kill the rest of the guards. They then let the rest of their detachment into the city. Tarentum has fallen to Hannibal.

title: Scipio Takes New Carthage
text: Cornelius Scipio takes over the ragged remains of the Roman army in Spain. His uncles had led the Roman war effort in Spain until they were both betrayed and killed in battle. With few resources and 27,500 men, Scipio sets out to take Spain from the Carthaginians. He starts by marching against the important stronghold of New Carthage. He gives his men a speech, promising them riches for success and claiming that his battle plan came to him in a dream from the god Neptune. After his first attack fails, Scipio sends a second attack against the city. Meanwhile, he takes 500 men to an undefended part of the walls protected by a lagoon. He has learned from the local fishermen that the lagoon is fordable at certain times of day. He and his men follow guides through the now shallow water and use ladders to climb the empty walls. Soon they take control of the city’s gate and let in the main attacking force. The Carthaginian commander soon surrenders and the Romans sack the city.

title: Scipio's Genius at Ilipa
text: Scipio and Hasdrubal have their armies camped near one another, waiting for battle. Each morning they draw up their battle lines, but neither side attacks. Both sides always place their strongest troops in the center and their weaker troops on the sides. One day, Scipio has his men wake and eat at dawn. He forms them up for battle and sends a raid against Hasdrubal’s camp. Hasdrubal forms his army up as usual. This is just what Scipio wanted. Scipio reverses his formation so his weaker soldiers are in the center and his stronger soldiers are on the sides. Scipio waits for hours. This makes his opponents grow hungary, as they haven't had breakfast.  Scipio then orders his army forward in a concave formation. This allows his strongest troops to fight Hasdrubal’s weakest troops while holding his weak center from engaging at all. The Carthaginian flanks are soon pushed back. At the same time, the Roman cavalry terrifies the enemy elephants who start to trample through the Carthaginian line. In the confusion, the Carthaginian army starts to flee. About 48,000 of Hasdrubal’s men die while Scipio loses only a few thousand. This is the end of Carthaginian power in Spain.

title: A New Invasion
text: After returning victorious from Spain, Scipio wins the consulship in a landslide. Even so, it is difficult to get his plan approved: an invasion of Africa. To fill his army, Scipio must turn to the legions that had survived the disaster at Cannae. Considered a disgrace to the Republic, they have been sent to serve far away in Sicily. With this army, Scipio lands in North Africa. There he joins forces with a new Roman ally, the Numidian prince Massinissa. Together they easily defeat Massinissa’s rival, the Numidian king Syphax, at the battle of the Great Plains. Syphax flees back to his kingdom and the Carthaginians begin peace talks with Scipio. While his terms are somewhat lenient, the Carthaginians still refuse them. They instead choose to recall Hannibal from Italy to defend Carthage itself.

title: Final Victory at Zama
text: After sixteen years of fighting in Italy, Hannibal returns to North Africa to defend his homeland. Scipio and Hannibal camp a few miles from each other by a place called Zama. Scipio captures three spies sent by Hannibal to scout out the Roman position. Rather than imprisoning them, Scipio gives them a full tour of the camp and sends them back to Hannibal. Scipio and Hannibal meet one another a few days before the battle. Little is certain about what they said, but it is likely they expressed mutual respect. Both generals had never lost a major battle. When their armies line up for battle, both know that the fate of their empires hang in the balance. Hannibal begins by sending his elephants forward. Scipio's cavalry are ready. They blow trumpets, scaring some elephants into trampling backwards through Hannibal’s army. The rest of the Roman army then moves to allow the remaining elephants to pass through without any casualties. Once the elephants are behind the army, they slaughtered by spearmen. Next, the Roman and Carthaginian cavalry meet. Now allied with Massinissa, the Romans finally have the advantage on horseback. Massinissa's men quickly win the fight and begin to chase their enemies. The infantry then clashed and fighting was intense. At one point both sides disengage and reform into long, thin lines. The Carthaginians begin to take the upper hand. The Carthaginians are about to win when Massinissa’s cavalry return. When they charge into Hannibal's rear the battle is over. The war was finally over. Rome had won.

title: The Carthaginian Surrender
text: Scipio offers harsh terms to the Carthaginian Senate. All Roman prisoners and deserters were to be handed over for execution. The Carthaginians were to surrender all their elephants and all but ten of their warships. Carthage was to abandon all its overseas territories. They were to pay 10,000 talents of silver over the following fifty years. They would also henceforth need Rome's permission to go to war. Carthage would now be considered a subordinate ally of Rome. At first the Carthaginian Senate debates whether to accept the terms. It is, of all people, Hannibal himself who settles the conversation. When one senator begins a speech arguing that they ought to reject the treaty, Hannibal physically pulls him off the speaker's position. He explains his behavior by saying that he has been absent for 36 years and has forgotten his etiquette. With Hannibal's support, the Carthaginian Senate accepts the terms. They will never again be a major power. About fifty years later, Rome would contrive reasons for a Third Punic War and burn Carthage to the ground. Rome had won dominance in the Western Mediterranean.
